importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed, marking the start of the obligations for Hamas to return deceased hostages.
The date on which two coffins containing the remains of deceased hostages crossed into Israel, signaling a major development in the implementation of the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: after the ceasefire deal went into effect
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe within which Hamas was supposed to return all deceased hostages under the Trump administration’s ceasefire agreement.

keyTakeAways: Two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred from Gaza into Israel by Hamas, escorted by Israeli military forces.
The bodies are being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification and investigation of cause of death.
This marks the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be returned since the ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025.
Hamas previously returned 13 of the 28 deceased hostages, all of which have been formally identified.
One of the bodies previously handed over was misidentified and did not belong to an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible errors in recovery or identification processes.
Israel’s intelligence agencies have assessed that Hamas may not be able to locate and return all remaining dead hostages due to the difficulty of recovery in war-damaged Gaza.
US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty of retrieving bodies buried under rubble and stated that this process is not going to happen overnight.
The transfer of bodies is part of a broader ceasefire agreement aimed at ending hostilities between Israel and Hamas, with both sides accusing each other of violations.
The US administration has not set a timeline for complete disarmament or full return of all deceased hostages, but has stressed the importance of returning bodies to families for burial.

namedEntities.name: Israeli military
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A governmental body responsible for national defense and border security
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Israeli military announced the arrival of the coffins and confirmed the transfer of the bodies into Israel, playing a central role in the operation's execution and public communication.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The main military force of Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF escorted the coffins and stated that the bodies are being transported to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, showing active involvement in the humanitarian and security aspects of the transfer.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A domestic intelligence agency in Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA co-issued a statement with the IDF, indicating its role in monitoring and assessing the security and compliance aspects of the ceasefire and hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Israel Ministry of Health
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A governmental body responsible for public health and medical services
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ministry confirmed that the bodies arrived at the forensic institute and is involved in the medical and human rights aspects of identifying deceased hostages.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group with political and military wings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is responsible for the transfer of the bodies under the ceasefire agreement and has been accused of misidentifying a body, indicating its role in compliance with the ceasefire terms.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades confirmed the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, showing direct involvement in the physical handling and delivery of the deceased bodies.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross was involved in the custody of the bodies before they were handed over to Israeli forces, indicating its role in humanitarian logistics and neutrality in conflict zones.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government under former President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration proposed the ceasefire deal and has expressed concern about the recovery of bodies, showing its diplomatic role in mediating the conflict and supporting the return of hostages.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Vice President under the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance visited Israel and publicly addressed the challenges of recovering bodies, underscoring the international political dimension of the hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli military officer who was a hostage
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification as one of the 13 formally identified bodies underscores the personal and emotional impact of the recovery process on Israeli families and the broader conflict narrative.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key institution in Israel responsible for forensic investigations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This facility is where the identification and cause-of-death analysis of the bodies are being conducted, playing a central role in the legal and humanitarian aspects of the case.

namedEntities.name: Ceasefire deal
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An agreement between Israel and Hamas to end hostilities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The return of the bodies is part of the ceasefire terms, and the failure or partial fulfillment of this component has raised concerns about compliance and trust in the agreement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military announced that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages have crossed into Israel from Gaza, following the implementation of a ceasefire agreement brokered by the Trump administration. The bodies are being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, marking the 14th and 15th deceased hostages returned since October 9. Hamas, under the terms of the deal, was required to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours, but Israel's intelligence agencies believe Hamas may not be able to locate all remaining bodies due to the war-damaged terrain and difficulty in recovery. One previously delivered body was misidentified and did not belong to an Israeli hostage. US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the immense difficulty of recovering bodies buried under rubble and stated that the process will not happen overnight. The incident highlights the fragility of the ceasefire, ongoing accusations of violations, and the deep human and political consequences of the conflict.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross into Israel
